{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Evangelos Marinakis | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1967|7|30}} | birth_place = [[Piraeus]], Greece | residence = [[Athens]], Greece
London, England | nationality = Greek | occupation = Businessman | boards = Chairman of Capital Maritime & Trading Corp.
Major Shareholder of Capital Product Partners L.P.
Owner of Alter Ego Media SA{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaneu.com/television-licenses/|title=On the way for the television licenses|author=|date=|website=www.balkaneu.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}}
Owner of Abisso Holdings Limited{{cite web|url=https://i-cyprus.com/company/400779|title=ABISSO HOLDINGS LIMITED / i-Cyprus — Cyprus Companies Search|author=|date=|website=i-cyprus.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}}
Owner of [[Olympiacos F.C.]]
Owner of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.]]
Municipal Councillor of [[Piraeus]] | spouse = Athanasia Marinakis | children = 4 | networth = [[US$]]650 million (2015){{cite web|author=Superyachtfan |url=http://www.superyachtfan.com/motor_yacht_amore_mio.html |title=Luxury Yacht Amore Mio II - Evangelos Marinakis |publisher=Superyachtfan.com |date= |accessdate=19 May 2017}}https://www.itsroundanditswhite.co.uk/articles/nottingham-forest-new-owner-evangelos-marinakis }} '''Evangelos Marinakis''' ({{lang-el|Ευάγγελος{{cite web|url=http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis |title=Evangelos Marinakis | Olympiacos.org / Official Website of Olympiacos Piraeus |publisher=Olympiacos.org |date= |accessdate=19 May 2017}} (Βαγγέλης) Μαρινάκης}}, born 30 July 1967) is a Greek shipowner and member of the [[Piraeus]] city council. He is the owner of the football clubs [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] in Greece and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in England. ==Early life== Evangelos Marinakis was born in Piraeus, Greece on 30 July 1967. He is the only son of Miltiadis Marinakis and Irini Marinaki (''née'' Karakatsani). His father, [[Miltiadis Marinakis]], was a shipowner, a Member of the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/fr/Organosi-kai-Leitourgia/Olomeleia/SInthesi-Proigoumenon-Periodon-New/?slctdPeriod=fdfcad51-0c28-4313-9c23-a47c421e007d&pageNo=13&pageNoR=3&SortByR=perifereia&SortDirectionR=asc|title=Composition des législatures antérieures|website=www.hellenicparliament.gr|access-date=29 September 2016}} and, at times, a financial supporter of Piraeus football club, [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]]. Evangelos Marinakis earned a [[B.A.]] in 'International Business Administration' and an [[M.Sc.]] in 'International Relations' in [[London]].{{cite web|title=Ο Βαγγέλης Μαρινάκης ταράζει τα νερά της ναυτιλίας|url=http://www.enikos.gr/economy/147452,O_Baggelhs_Marinakhs_tarazei_ta_nera_ths.html|publisher=enikos.gr|accessdate=22 November 2013}} ==Career== ===Shipping=== Marinakis is the founder and chairman of Capital Maritime & Trading Corp.{{cite web|title = Evangelos Marinakis|url = http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis|website = Olympiacos.org {{!}} Official Website of Olympiacos Piraeus|access-date = 11 January 2016}} From March 2010 until September 2011, he also served as [[Chairman]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[NYSE]]-listed Crude Carriers Corp.{{cite web|url=http://shipping.capitallink.com/interviews/2010/MarinakisInterview032210.pdf |title=Evangelos Marinakis, the CEO of Crude Carriers, Discusses the Strengths of the Company. Interview with Barry Parker of BDP1 |publisher= Capital Link Shipping |date=23 March 2010 |accessdate=19 December 2012}} Between March 2007 and December 2014{{cite news|title=Marinakis makes way|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/archive/?q=marinakis|accessdate=23 December 2014|newspaper=Tradewinds|date=18 December 2014}} he was chairman of Capital Product Partners L.P. ([[NASDAQ]]:CPLP). From 1992 to 2005, Marinakis was the commercial manager of Capital Ship Management Corp. and oversaw the businesses of the group of companies that now form Capital Maritime. For the past decades, he has also been active in several other family-controlled businesses all related to the shipping industry.{{cite web|title = Capital Product Partners L.P. - Annual Report for Foreign Private Issuers|url = http://www.capitalpplp.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1193125-14-57161&CIK=1392326|website = www.capitalpplp.com|access-date = 11 January 2016}} === Awards & distinctions === Having "grown his shipping empire from the small company he took over from his father, which controlled seven bulk carriers",{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Gillian|title=Marinakis. The Man behind the Legend|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/TWplus/|accessdate=20 May 2015|issue=Spring 2015|publisher=TradeWinds tw+. The Quarterly Tradewinds Publication|date=13 March 2015}} he is regarded as one of the most important and influential shipping personalities worldwide. He was included in the [[Lloyd's List]] "One Hundred Most Influential People in the Shipping Industry" list, ranking 66th in 2017,{{Cite web|url=https://lloydslist.maritimeintelligence.informa.com/LL1120251/66-Evangelos-Marinakis-Capital-Group|title=66 Evangelos Marinakis, Capital Group|last=|first=|date=14 December 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 January 2018}} ranking 61st in 2016,{{cite web|url=https://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article543988.ece|title=61. Evangelos Marinakis, Capital Maritime & Trading|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ranking 65th in 2015,{{cite web|title = Lloyd's List - Top 100|url = http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/?pg=6|website = www.lloydslist.com|accessdate = 17 December 2015}} 67th in 2014, 73rd in 2013{{cite news|title=ONE HUNDRED 2013 MOST INFLUENTIAL PEOPLE IN THE SHIPPING INDUSTRY. NO 73. Evangelos Marinakis, Capital|url=http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/top100/article433629.ece|accessdate=17 December 2013|newspaper=Lloyd's List|date=12 December 2013}} and 84th in 2012. He was also included in the [[TradeWinds]] "Power 100" list of the ‘top shipowners and operators", ranking 31st in 2012{{cite news|title=Power 2012: Top 50 Owners and Operators (2 to 50)|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/weekly/278337/power-2012-top-50-owners-and-operators-2-to-50|accessdate=20 May 2015|publisher=TradeWinds|date=31 May 2012}} and 75th in 2010.{{cite news|title=(Power 100) 75. "EvangelosMarinakis Capital Maritime/ Crude Carriers, Athens|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/weekly/136523/power-100-75-evangelos-marinakis-capital-maritime-crude-carriers-athens |accessdate=20 May 2015|publisher=TradeWinds|date=11 June 2010}} In 2014{{cite news|title=Greek Shipping Awards 2014|url=http://www.allaboutshipping.co.uk/2014/12/11/greek-shipping-awards-2014/|accessdate=20 May 2015|publisher=All About Shipping}} and 2010{{cite web|title=Lloyd's List Greek Shipping Awards 2010. The Winners. Newsmaker of the Year. Winner: Evangelos Marinakis|url=http://books.informa.com.au/2010_GSA/#/4/|publisher=Lloyd's List|accessdate=20 December 2012}} he was awarded the "Newsmaker of the Year" award at the annual [[Lloyd's List]] "Greek Shipping Awards",{{cite web|title=Marinakis Voted "Greek Shipping Newsmaker Of The Year" At The 2014 Lloyd's List Greek Shipping Awards|url=http://www.shippingherald.com/Admin/ArticleDetail/ArticleDetailsShippingNews/tabid/98/ArticleID/18405/Marinakis-Voted-Greek-Shipping-Newsmaker-Of-The-Year-At-The-2014-Lloyds-List-Greek-Shipping-Awards.aspx|publisher=Shipping Herald. The Maritime Portal.|accessdate=20 May 2015|date=10 December 2014}} while in 2009 his company, Capital Ship Management Corp. was awarded the "Tanker Company of the Year" award.{{cite web|title=Capital Ship Management Corp voted tanker company of the year|url=https://www.intertanko.com/News-Desk/Weekly-News/Year-2009/No-50-2009/|publisher=Intertanko|accessdate=20 May 2015}} In 2016, he was awarded the first ever "Xenakoudis Excellence in Shipping Award" by the International Registries, Inc./The Marshall Islands Registry. {{Cite news|url=http://www.maritime-executive.com/article/marinakis-wins-award-from-marshall-islands-registry|title=Marinakis Wins Award from Marshall Islands Registry|work=The Maritime Executive|access-date=28 March 2017}} In November 2017, Marinakis received the [[Lloyd's List|Lloyd’s List]] "Greek Shipping Personality of the Year" Award at a special ceremony in Athens. Nigel Lowry of Lloyd’s List said Marinakis was the "outstanding candidate" for the award and noted his $1 billion investment in fleet capacity in 2017, his "dynamic dealmaking" in the shipping sector, as well as a range of other activities across philanthropy, sports and media.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/sport/football/football-news/nottingham-forest-owner-evangelos-marinakis-844573|title=Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis the 'outstanding candidate' for special award|last=|first=|date=28 November 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 December 2017}} === Political career === In May 2014, Marinakis was elected first member of the Piraeus city council with the ''Piraeus Winner'' independent ticket,{{cite web|url=http://www.pireasnet.gr/%CE%9C%CE%91%CE%A1%CE%99%CE%9D%CE%91%CE%9A%CE%97%CE%A3%CE%95%CE%A5%CE%91%CE%93%CE%93%CE%95%CE%9B%CE%9F%CE%A3MARINAKISEVANGELOS/tabid/1400/Default.aspx|title=LOCAL COUNCILLOR - EVANGELOS M. MARINAKIS|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=MUNICIPALITY OF PIRAEUS OFFICIAL WEBSITE|access-date=}} that he co-founded with [[Yannis Moralis (politician)|Yannis Moralis]], vice-president of [[Olympiacos F.C.]].{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/greece-vote-port-idUSL6N0O53BD20140523|title = Shipping tycoon makes rare political foray in Greek port town|date = 23 May 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Among their pledges were the preservation of the public nature of [[Piraeus]] Port Authority and the development of Piraeus as Europe’s largest cruise ship destination and home port.{{cite news|title=Moralis : "Our problem is that shipowners left from Piraeus"|url=http://en.protothema.gr/moralis-our-problem-is-that-shipowners-left-from-piraeus/|accessdate=23 June 2015|date=1 May 2014}} During the elections, his political opponent, Vassilis Michaloliakos, claimed Marinakis was related with the far right political party [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] and accused him for its financial support.{{cite web|title=Golden Dawn’s consolidation and its reluctant prosecution|url=http://roarmag.org/2015/02/greece-golden-dawn-prosecution/|publisher=roarmag.org|accessdate=}} Marinakis rejected these accusations stating "I condemn Golden Dawn's criminal activity".{{cite web|title=Piraeus mayor accuses opponent of deal with Golden Dawn|url=http://www.enetenglish.gr/?i=news.en.article&id=1951|publisher=enetenglish.gr|accessdate=}} After the election, ''[[Reuters]]'' declared that "rarely has big business mingled so openly with politics in a country where contacts between the two are usually conducted behind the scenes". Marinakis responded, in a [[TradeWinds (newspaper)|Tradewinds]] interview, that he can see no reason why someone with a strong record in business cannot get into politics, "calling that stance "Palaiolithic logic". "I am not afraid to be involved in politics, because I have no business with the Greek state" he said. Since the elections, he undertook the construction of squares, parks, children’s playgrounds and sports facilities, at his own cost, as the municipality of Piraeus lacks the necessary funds due to the economic crisis.{{cite news|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/TWplus/355684/marinakis-the-man-behind-the-legend|title=Marinakis. The man behind The Legend|last=|first=|date=13 March 2015|work=|newspaper=Tradewinds|access-date=|via=|accessdate=23 June 2015}} ===Sports=== Since mid-2010 Marinakis has owned [[Piraeus]]' hometown team [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], and serves as its President.According to the [http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis][[Olympiacos]] website official biography Marinakis served as president of the [[Superleague Greece]] and vice-president of the [[Hellenic Football Federation]] (HFF) from August 2010 until September 2011. During his presidency of Olympiacos, the team won the Greek League title for seven consecutive seasons from 2010–11 to 2016–17, and the National Cup for the 2011–12, 2012–13 and 2014–15 seasons. In May 2017, it was announced that Marinakis had completed a transaction to become the majority shareholder in English Championship club and former double European Cup winners [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/nottingham-forest-football-club-press-release-3719464.aspx|title=Nottingham Forest Football Club have released the following statement regarding the take-over by Mr Evangelos M. Marinakis|last=NFFC|access-date=18 May 2017|language=en}} The ''[[Nottingham Post]]'' noted that Marinakis’ acquisition of the club heralds “an exciting future that gives genuine reason for optimism”. Meanwhile, manager [[Mark Warburton]] commented that he expects Marinakis and his team to be ambitious for Nottingham Forest. “..they are aware of the club's stature and they are good football people,” Warburton was quoted as saying. {{Cite news|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/nottingham-forest-talking-point-fine-lines-mean-so-much-as-evangelos-marinakis-plans-new-era/story-30335904-detail/story.html|title=Fine lines mean so much as Evangelos Marinakis plans new era|date=17 May 2017|work=Nottingham Post|access-date=18 May 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.forest.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=581453#ixzz4hQRYlus0|title=Warburton Expecting Aggressive Marinakis Ambitions {{!}} VitalFootball.co.uk|last=Ltd|first=Vitalnetwork|work=VitalFootball.co.uk|access-date=18 May 2017}} === Media === In September 2016, Marinakis, through his company Alter Ego Media S.A., won one of four national television licenses auctioned in Greece after spending EUR 73.9m ($82.8m) in a highly unusual competitive bidding process.{{cite web|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/incoming/775802/marinakis-wins-greek-tv-licence|title=Marinakis wins Greek TV licence|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Tradewinds News|access-date=2 September 2016}} The license was however revoked on 26 October 2016 since the [[Council of State (Greece)| Greek Council of State]] held that the TV license law of [[Minister of State]] [[Nikos Pappas (politician)|Nikos Pappas]] was unconstitutional. In July 2017, Alter Ego was confirmed by a Greek first-instance court as the acquirer of the [[Lambrakis Press Group]] (DOL).{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2017/07/25/greek-court-confirms-transfer-of-lambrakis-media-group-to-vangelis-marinakis/|title=Greek Court Confirms Transfer of Lambrakis Media Group to Vangelis Marinakis - GreekReporter.com|author=|date=|website=greece.greekreporter.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}} The court approval for the transfer ownership of DOL to Alter Ego followed the latter’s success as the highest bidder in an auction process held earlier in 2017. The court ratified the sale and granted a request by DOL staff that the auction procedure be accepted as valid. The completion of the transfer of ownership was also supported by trade unions representing DOL staff. DOL is one of Greece’s historic major media groups and includes the top selling [[Ta Nea]] and [[To Vima]] newspapers, two of the country's oldest dailies, as well as a popular news portal, magazines and radio station. As of March 2018 the agreement for DOL has not yet been approved by the Competition Committee.{{cite web|url=http://cyprusnews.eu/tvxs-epistimi/7297995-%CE%B5%CE%BC%CF%80%CE%BB%CE%BF%CE%BA%CE%AE-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%BC%CE%B5%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%B2%CE%AF%CE%B2%CE%B1%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%B4%CE%BF%CE%BB-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF%CE%BD-%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AC%CE%BA%CE%B7.html|title=Εμπλοκή στη μεταβίβαση του ΔΟΛ στον Μαρινάκη|first=|last=Administrator|date=|website=cyprusnews.eu|accessdate=28 March 2018}} It also holds a 22% stake in [[Mega Channel]] TV station. {{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-07/25/c_136469236.htm|title=Greek shipowner Marinakis acquires media group DOL - Xinhua - English.news.cn|author=|date=|website=news.xinhuanet.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}} == Philanthropy == He has a role as a philanthropist, both privately and as president of Olympiacos F.C. Σισέ|last=|first=|date=27 March 2017|website=Sport24.gr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 June 2018}} In 2015, the Public Prosecutor{{cite web|title = AIPS Web Site - Full and complete acquittal for Olympiacos president Marinakis|url = http://www.aipsmedia.com/index.php?page=news&cod=16230&tp=n|website = www.aipsmedia.com|access-date = 11 January 2016}} and the Council of |website = ESPN soccer|publisher = |last = |first = }} Marinakis was charged with complicity to commit acts of [[bribery]] and match manipulation,{{cite web|url = http://www.thepressproject.net/article/65820/The-alleged-corruption-of-Evangelos-Marinakis-and-the-press-that-refuses-to-report-on-it|title = The alleged corruption of Evangelos Marinakis and the http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_11/07/2011_397915|title = Vangelis Marinakis in fresh trouble|date = 11 July 2011|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} Marinakis, along with the president of [[Second Division (Greece)|second-division]] club [[Ilioupoli F.C.|Ilioupoli]], Giorgos Tsakogiannis and others, cooperated so that a group of hardcore Olympiacos fans would travel on 13 March 2011 to a [[Third Division (Greece)|third division]] match and provoke [[riots]] to bring about a penalty. The prosecutor’s report says that "Tsakogiannis informed [Ioannis] [[Papadopoulos]] that he had made arrangements and Evangelos Marinakis was aware of the plan for Olympiacos fans to cause riots". Marinakis was acquitted from all charges by the Prosecutor, Panagiotis Poulios,{{cite web|title = Η απαλλαγή του Βαγγέλη Μαρινάκη|url = http://newpost.gr/athlitika/456770/h-apallagh-toy-baggelh-marinakh|website = Newpost.gr|access-date = 11 January 2016}} and the Council of Judges.{{Cite news|title = Απαλλαγή Μαρινάκη σε δίκη 84 για τα Στημένα|date = 31 July 2015|work = Εθνοσπόρ}} In 2014, Marinakis was acquitted by the Three Members Court of First Instance relatively to the case of entering the referee's (Thanassis Yiachos's) locker room at halftime{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_30/05/2013_501734|title = Cup Final referee says Olympiacos chairman entered his locker room at halftime|date = 30 May 2013|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} during the football cup final between Olympiacos and [[Asteras Tripolis]], against football regulations to complain about the decisions taken. Marinakis stated that he went to the referee’s locker room at halftime only to wish match officials "good luck". Olympiacos went on and won the match 3–1, after a tense 1–1 at halftime.{{cite web|url = http://www.thepressproject.net/article/65820/The-alleged-corruption-of-Evangelos-Marinakis-and-the-press-that-refuses-to-report-on-it|title = The alleged corruption of Evangelos Marinakis and the press that refuses to report on it|date = |accessdate = |website = The Press Project|publisher = |last = |first = }} In 2015 Marinakis was also acquitted by the Three Members Court of Appeals for the same case.{{cite web|url = http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/blog/broken-promises-the-sad-tale-of-greek-football/|title = Broken promises – the sad tale of Greek football|date = 2 October 2014|accessdate = |website = Epoch Times|publisher = |last = |first = }} Another investigation which led to the [[2015 Greek football scandal]], started in 2014 after [[prosecutor]] Aristidis Koreas was given the go-ahead by a council of judges{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_08/07/2014_541220|title = Probe into Greek soccer corruption gathers pace|date = 8 July 2014|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} to make use of secretly recorded phone conversations{{cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-13914118|title = Dozens named in Greece football 'scandal'|date = 25 June 2011|accessdate = |website = BBC News|publisher = |last = |first = }} that point to the involvement of various sports officials, including Evangelos Marinakis. According to Koreas, "the president of Olympiakos and close associates approached and tried to use policemen, judges, politicians and other powerful figures for their own ends as part of the planning and establishment of a criminal organization". According to the prosecutor, Marinakis was helped by the President of the Greek Football Association, Giorgos Sarris, to choose specific referees to oversee key games.{{cite news|title=Marinakis denies fixing|url=http://www.thepressproject.net/article/65820/The-alleged-corruption-of-Evangelos-Marinakis-and-the-press-that-refuses-to-report-on-it|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=ThePressProject}} He has repeatedly denied all charges:{{cite news|title=Marinakis denies fixing|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/andalso/article147701.ece5|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=Tradewinds|date=27 June 2011}} "These allegations have nothing to do with me and have no effect on me whatsoever," Marinakis said. "There is not one shred of evidence against me."{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/6699614/greek-league-chief-vangelis-marinakis-linked-corruption-scandal |title=Vangelis Marinakis among 68 suspects|publisher=ESPN Soccer from Associated Press|date=24 June 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2012}} On 3 October 2014, Aristidis Koreas, though he was replaced as athletic prosecutor, he remained on the case.{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_03/10/2014_543434|title = Officials probing Greek soccer corruption removed from cases|date = 3 October 2014|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} Evangelos Marinakis was questioned on 18 June 2015 and he was released on a €200,000 bail. He was also forced to stop being involved in any football activity, as well as he must report to a police station every 15 days.{{cite web | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9888897/olymiakos-owner-vangelis-marinakis-banned-from-football-over-corruption-allegations | title=Olympiakos owner Vangelis Marinakis banned from football over corruption allegations | publisher = skysports.com | date = 18 June 2015}}{{cite web | url = http://www.eurosport.com/football/owner-of-greek-champions-banned-over-corruption-probe_sto4787854/story.shtml | title=Owner of Greek champions banned over corruption probe | publisher = eurosport.com | date = 18 June 2015}} In September 2016, the prosecutor proposed the imprisonment of Mr Marinakis.{{cite web|url=http://www.pronews.gr/elliniki-politiki/kyvernisi/479479_kai-xafnika-meizon-provlima-marinaki-gia-tin-kyvernisi-tin-amesi|title=Και ξαφνικά μείζον πρόβλημα Μαρινάκη για την κυβέρνηση: Την άμεση σύλληψη και προφυλάκισή του προτείνει ο εισαγγελέας Εφετών|author=|date=|website=pronews.gr|accessdate=14 March 2018}} In November 2017, the judicial council of the Court of Appeals rejected imposing provisional custody on Evangelos Marinakis and also dropped various charges after deeming them "absolutely groundless".{{Cite web|url=http://news.in.gr/english/article/?aid=1500173843|title=Marinakis: I shall be vindicated on all charges|last=|first=|date=10 November 2017|website=In.gr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2018}} Marinakis was also resigned from president of the team due to legal reasons, giving his seat to Yiannis Moralis.{{cite web|url=http://www.fortunegreece.com/article/episima-o-moralis-neos-proedros-tou-olimpiakou/|title=Επίσημα ο Γιάννης Μώραλης νέος πρόεδρος του Ολυμπιακού - ΕΠΙΚΑΙΡΟΤΗΤΑ - Fortunegreece.com|author=|date=16 November 2017|website=fortunegreece.com|accessdate=28 March 2018}} On 26 March 2018, Marinakis was vindicated by the Greek Supreme Court. The decision of the Greek Supreme Court confirmed that the allegations against him were unfounded.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nottinghampost.com/sport/football/nottingham-forest-owner-evangelos-marinakis-1387363|title=Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis issues statement after being cleared of match-fixing in Greece|last=|first=|date=26 March 2018|website=Nottingham Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 April 2018}} ===Drug trafficking=== In March 2018, Marinakis was charged with trafficking heroin by [[prosecutor|public prosecutor]] Irene Tziva. The accusations against Marinakis were described as "very serious charges" following a three-year investigation after the tanker Noor One was intercepted at the Greek port of [[Piraeus]] carrying 2.1 tonnes of heroin in 2014. He has also been charged with financing an illegal operation.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43527262|title=Evangelos Marinakis: Nottingham Forest owner rejects drugs link|author=|date=24 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=28 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} Nottingham Forest F.C. chairman Nicholas Randall wrote an open letter to supporters reaffirming his support for Evangelos Marinakis. Randall confirmed the matter was under investigation but that "there is no ‘charge’ against Marinakis and no ‘prosecution’ is in process."{{cite web|title=No drug charge for Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/no-drug-charge-for-forest-owner-evangelos-marinakis-gmw2fk6l0|website=The Times|accessdate=18 May 2018|date=29 March 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marinakis, Evangelos}} [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:Olympiacos F.C. presidents]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Greek chief executives]] [[Category:Nottingham Forest F.C.]] [[Category:Greek football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:English football chairmen and investors]]

{{*}}[[Patriot War of East Florida]] |awards= }} '''George Mathews''' ({{OldStyleDateDY|August 30, |1739|August 19, 1739}} – {{nowrap|August 30, 1812}}) was a [[Continental Army]] officer during the [[American Revolutionary War]] and rose to the rank of [[brevet (military)|brevet]] brigadier general; he was [[Governors of Georgia|Governor of Georgia]], and a [[U.S. Congressman]]. He was the leading participant in the [[Patriot War (Seminole Wars)|Patriot War]] of East Florida, an 1810–1812 [[filibuster (military)|filibuster]] expedition to capture [[Spanish Florida]] for the United States. Born in [[Augusta County]], [[Virginia]], Mathews was in early life a merchant and planter. He quickly became a senior officer in the colonial forces, and was credited along with Colonel [[Andrew Lewis (soldier)|Andrew Lewis]] for the victory of the Virginia provincial militia against the [[Shawnee]] and [[Mingo Indian]] tribes in the [[Battle of Point Pleasant]] of [[Dunmore's War]]. He was afterward a member of the [[Virginia House of Burgesses|House of Burgesses]] from Augusta County. He attended the [[First Virginia Convention]] when the [[Virginia General Assembly]] was dissolved by [[List of colonial governors of Virginia|royal governor]] [[John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore|Lord Dunmore]]. On the outbreak of the [[American Revolutionary War]] Mathews led the [[9th Virginia Regiment]] of the [[Continental Army]] to the [[Battle of Brandywine]] in September 1777. He and his entire regiment were captured in the [[Battle of Germantown]] the following month. He spent the next four years as a [[prisoner of war]], including two years on the British [[prison ship]] {{HMS|Jersey}}. He was exchanged on December 5, 1781. He was breveted to the rank of brigadier general on September 30, 1783. He was an original member of the Virginia [[Society of the Cincinnati]]. After the war, he moved to the state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and was quickly elected to the [[Georgia General Assembly]]. The same year he was elected 20th [[Governors of Georgia|governor]] of the state. He served two terms as governor, and one intermittent term in [[United States Congress|Congress]], during which he voted to [[Ratification of the United States Constitution|ratify the United States Constitution]]. During his second administration he quietly allowed the creation of the rogue state of the [[Trans-Oconee Republic]], headed by General [[Elijah Clarke]]. He oversaw the removal of the state when public opinion, coupled with pressure from the Federal government, shifted. His administration was later tainted by the [[Yazoo Land Fraud]], which ultimately led to his retirement from politics. Mathews relocated to the [[Mississippi Territory]] and in 1810 was assigned a [[Filibuster (military)|filibuster]] operation by President [[James Madison]] to incite an insurrection in [[East Florida]] and capture the territory for the United States. This initiative is now referred to as the [[Patriot War (Seminole Wars)|Patriot War]] of East Florida. Mathews had launched the insurrection, capturing [[Fernandina Beach, Florida|Ferninanda Beach]] and [[Amelia Island]], before the secret mission was recalled and disowned by President Madison, fearing war with Spain and its allies. On learning of the recall, Mathews set out to [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] to confront Madison on the decision. He died in [[Augusta, Georgia]] on his way to the capital. He is buried at [[St. Paul's Episcopal Church (Augusta, Georgia)|St. Paul's Episcopal Church]]. == Early life == George Mathews was born on August 30, 1739 in [[Augusta County, Virginia]] to Anne (née Archer) and John Mathews.{{cite journal|last1=Herndon|first1=G. Melvin|title=George Mathews, Frontier Patriot|journal=Virginia Magazine of History and Biography|date=1969|volume=77|issue=3|page=307|jstor=4247487}} His parents immigrated to America during the early years of the [[Scotch-Irish American|Scotch-Irish]] on 1717–1775."... summer of 1717 ...", [[David Hackett Fischer|Fischer, David Hackett]], ''[[Albion's Seed: Four British Folkways in America]]'', Oxford University Press, USA (March 14, 1989), pg. 606; "... early immigration was small, ... but it began to surge in 1717.", Blethen, H.T. & Wood, C.W., ''From Ulster to Carolina'', North Carolina Division of Archives and History, 2005, pg. 22; "Between 1718 and 1775", Griffin, Patrick, ''The People with No Name'', Princeton University Press, 2001, pg 1; etc. His father was a successful member of the early Augusta County community and sent George and his siblings to the Augusta Academy, a local classical school founded in 1749.Patrick, Rembert W. (2010). Florida Fiasco: Rampant Rebels on the Georgia-Florida Border, 1810–1815. University of Georgia Press, 2010. {{ISBN|0820335495}}, 9780820335490 By the 1760s George and a brother, [[Sampson Mathews]] had acquired extensive property along the western frontier as far west as the [[Greenbrier County, West Virginia|Greenbrier district]], and set up several outpost along this stretch. They sold both frontier necessities and specialty goods and their imports included Atlantic trade markets.Handley, Harry E. (1963), "The Mathews Trading Post", published in The Journal of the Greenbrier Historical Society: Volume 1, Number 1 (Lewisburg, West Virginia: Greenbrier Historical Society, August 1963) http://www.gillilandtrails.org/pages/MathewsTradingPost.asp Retrieved October 28, 2012 He was active in civic affairs of his community, holding the offices of [[Sheriffdom|sheriff]], [[vestryman]], and [[justice of the peace]] for Augusta County, and he was regularly involved in skirmishes against local Native American tribes, who frequently conducted raids into the colonies. His father's farm was raided on at least one occasion.Chalkley, Lyman (1912) Chronicles of the Scotch-Irish Settlement in Virginia, Extracted from the Original Court Records of Augusta County, 1745–1800 (Washington, D.C.: Daughters of the American Revolution, 1912). In the fall of 1774, Royal Governor [[Lord Dunmore]] assembled an invasion of Native American Virginia territory as a result of the rising tension between the two peoples, culling a thousand troops largely from the Virginia frontier. George Mathews was commissioned captain of Augusta County militia under Colonel [[Andrew Lewis (soldier)|Andrew Lewis]], whom he accompanied to [[Point Pleasant, West Virginia|Point Pleasant, Virginia (now West Virginia)]]. The October 1774 [[Battle of Point Pleasant]] of [[Dunmore's War]] was fought between Virginia militia and Native Americans from the [[Shawnee]] and [[Mingo]] tribes along the [[Ohio River]]. The Native Americans, under the Shawnee Chief [[Cornstalk]], attacked Virginia militia under Col. Lewis, attempting to halt Lewis's advance into the [[Ohio Country]].Atkinson, George W., ''History of Kanawha County: from its organization in 1789 until the present time''; Printed at the Office of the West Virginia Journal, 1876, 345 pgs. Rembert Patrick described the battle as "a typical Indian battle where every man found a tree, and military discipline in the English sense was unknown." Mathews was credited with a flanking maneuver late in the battle that initiated Cornstalk's retreat.Herndon, G. Melvin (1969). George Mathews, Frontier Patriot. The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. 77, No. 3 (Jul., 1969) pp. 307-328Stuart, Charles (1845). Charles A. Stuart to Lyman C. Draper, Greenbrier, January 8, 1845 in Draper Collection, Kentucky Papers, VIII, 40. He gained statewide fame from the battle was elected to the [[Virginia House of Burgesses|House of Burgesses]] for the 1774 session, though Governor Dunmore dissolved the assembly before it convened. In May 1774, he attended the [[First Virginia Convention]].Leonard, Cynthia Miller 1978. The General Assembly of Virginia, July 30, 1619-January 11, 1978: a bicentennial register of members. Virginia State Library., pp 105, 109. The Burgesses, operating as the First Virginia Convention, met on August 1, 1774 and elected representatives to the Second Virginia Convention, banned commerce and payment of debts with Britain, and pledged aid and supplies to the [[American Revolution]]. == American Revolutionary War == [[File:Germantown.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|American forces lay siege during the [[Battle of Germantown]]]] George Mathews was commissioned colonel of the [[9th Virginia Regiment]] in the [[Continental Army]] on the outbreak of the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] and led the regiment north to join the General [[George Washington]] and the [[Continental Army]] for the [[Battle of Brandywine]] of the [[Philadelphia campaign]]. The battle, fought between Washington's army and the British army of General [[William Howe, 5th Viscount Howe|Sir William Howe]] on September 11, 1777, consisted primarily of hand-to-hand bayonet combat. The British defeated the Americans and forced them to withdraw toward the rebel capital of [[Philadelphia]]. Mathews was credited for saving the American army from rout at the battle, during which he was said to have been stabbed 5–7 times. [[Alexander Scott Withers]] declared him the "hero of Brandywine." The following month, he and his entire regiment were killed, captured, or scattered at the [[Battle of Germantown]], a second clash between generals Washington and Howe. Mathews led a charge early in the day that resulted in the capture up to 100 British soldiers; however, as the day progressed, his regiment had penetrated so deeply into British lines that it became isolated from Washington's army and was engulfed by opposing troops. The given reasons for his capture vary; some claim he did not receive Washington's orders to retreat, while others claim his regiment became lost in the fog and smoke of battle. He spent much of the remaining revolution as a [[American Revolution prisoners of war|prisoner of war]], at first held at [[Philadelphia]]. When the British withdrew from there, he was moved to the [[prison ship]] {{HMS|Jersey|1736|6}}, anchored in [[New York harbor]]. [[File:Interior HMS Jersey 1855.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|Interior of {{HMS|Jersey|1736|6}}]] By 1779 he was granted a limited ''[[parole]]'' and permitted to live in New York City. He wrote to Governor [[Thomas Jefferson]] and to the [[Continental Congress]] urging a [[prisoner exchange]]. Jefferson wrote to Mathews to explain his decision to leave him in New York City as a parolee and instead exchange for others still suffering on the prison ships: {{quote box |width = 50em |border = 1px |align = center |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |halign = left |quote = Your situation indeed seems to have been better since you were sent to New York [City], but reflect on what you suffered before that and know others of your countrymen to suffer and what you know is now suffered by that more unhappy part of them who are still confined on board the prison ships of the enemy. |source= — Thomas Jefferson letter to George Mathews, ''The Works of Thomas Jefferson, Vol. II (in 12 Volumes): Correspondence 1771–1779, the Summary View, and the Declaration of Independence.'' (2010) Ford, Paul L. The Works of Thomas Jefferson, Vol. II (in 12 Volumes): Correspondence 1771–1779, the Summary View, and the Declaration of Independence. Cosimo classics history Volume 2 of The Works of Thomas Jefferson. p467. https://books.google.com/books?id=Iry86J8v01AC&pg=PA467 Retrieved November 3, 2012 }} He was finally exchanged on December 5, 1781, at which point he went south with Major General [[Nathanael Greene|Nathaniel Greene]], campaigning in [[South Carolina]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and fighting with Greene at the [[Battle of Guilford Court House]]. He was named commander of the [[12th Virginia Regiment]], but this was only a nominal command, since his new regiment had been prisoners since the fall of [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]] in May 1780. He was brevetted to the rank of brigadier general on September 30, 1781. == Political career in Georgia== Mathews was impressed with the opportunities for political and financial gain on the Georgia frontier during his campaign with Gen. Greene. When he was released from service in 1783, he bought land in [[Wilkes County, Georgia|Wilkes County]], augmenting that with [[land grant]]s given for Revolutionary War service. He liquidated his Virginia property, and moved his family to a [[log cabin]] there. He and his wife, Polly, would raise their children there and in their later, larger house. In all, they had eight: John, Charles Lewis, [[George Mathews (judge)|George]], William, Ann, Jane, Margaret, and Rebecca. [[File:ElijahClarkeByRembrandtPeale.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|General [[Elijah Clarke]] organized the [[Trans-Oconee Republic]] in 1794]] He became a judge in Wilkes County, and a town commissioner for [[Washington, Georgia]]. In 1787 he was a successful candidate for the [[Georgia General Assembly|Georgia Assembly]]. His bearing and military experience gained the respect of the other members, and they named him 20th [[Governor of Georgia|Governor]] of Georgia in 1787. Following his term in the governor's office he was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 1789 for one term, during which he attended the state convention to ratify the [[United States Constitution]]. His identification as a [[United States Federalist Party|Federalist]] and his involvement in [[land speculation]] caused him to lose the election for the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] in 1792. But, by 1793 he had regained enough support to again be chosen governor. His second administration was more tumultuous than his first. In February 1794, General [[Elijah Clarke]], a popular veteran of the [[American Revolutionary War]], lead an expedition to establish an independent state west of the [[Oconee River]]—on hunting grounds reserved by the federal [[Treaty of New York (1790)]] exclusively for the [[Creek Indians]]. Georgia had not been consulted on the original treaty and many Georgians viewed it unfavorably because they saw it as limiting the possibilities for the future expansion of their state.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Pbbiqe9o0lEC&dq=The+Georgia-Florida+Frontier,+1793-1796:+Spanish+Reaction+to+French+Intrigue+and+American+Designs&source=gbs_navlinks_s George R. Lamplugh, ''Politics on the Periphery: Factions and Parties in Georgia, 1783-1806''], Newark, University of Delaware Press, 1986, pp. 64-68, accessed 19 Nov 2010 Clarke's [[frontier]]smen made settlements on lands in present-day [[Greene County, Georgia|Greene]], [[Morgan County, Georgia|Morgan]], [[Putnam County, Georgia|Putnam]], and [[Baldwin County, Georgia|Baldwin]] counties of Georgia. The settlers built several towns and forts over the next few months. They also wrote and ratified their own constitution, indicating the permanent intention of their endeavor. With little overt opposition from the Creek, they were taking control of the lands before the state or federal governments could react.[http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-2532 Christopher J. Floyd, "Trans-Oconee Republic"], ''New Georgia Encyclopedia'', 2004–2010, accessed 19 Nov 2010 The United States government viewed Clarke's actions as a violation of the Treaty of New York, which provided recognition of Creek lands in an effort to maintain peace and guarantee their neutrality. President [[George Washington]] pressured Mathews to remove the illegal settlers from the Creek lands. Mathews initially ignored the "unauthorized military expedition", because he shared the state's resentment of the treaty and was aware of Clarke's popularity as a hero of the Revolution. He took only token measures to stop Clarke and his party, such as issuing a proclamation in July 1794 that went unenforced. It is unlikely that Mathews had enough public support to move against Clarke at that juncture, but the tide of public opinion eventually changed and he took actions to remove the rogue general from power. In September, 1200 Georgia militiamen, acting in conjunction with federal troops stationed on the Oconee, surrounded and isolated General Clarke's fortifications. After some negotiation, Clarke agreed to surrender, provided that he and his men would not face prosecution for their actions. Clarke and his followers departed, and the militia burned down the new settlements and fortifications. [[Image:Yazoo-Georgia Controversy.png|thumb|upright=1.0|The three areas that constituted the 1789 [[Yazoo land scandal]]. The fraud led to Mathews' political downfall.]] Mathews' popularity waned, in 1794 he turned to [[land speculation]] in an effort to maintain his popularity. He, along with other high-ranking Georgia officials, issued several grants of land for the same parcels, at times granting up to three times more land than existed. Four new companies: the Georgia Company, the Georgia-Mississippi Company, the Upper Mississippi Company, and the new Tennessee Company, persuaded the Georgia state assembly to sell more than 40,000,000 acres (160,000 km2) of land for $500,000. Many Georgia officials and legislators were to be stockholders in these companies. On January 7, 1795, Mathews signed into law a bill authorizing the sale of the 40,000,000 acres (160,000 km2), known as the Yazoo Act. When the details were revealed, public outrage was widespread, and people protested to federal officials and Congressmen. [[Jared Irwin]] and U.S. Senator [[James Jackson (Georgia politician)|James Jackson]] led the reform efforts: Irwin was elected Governor of Georgia and, less than two months after taking office, signed a bill on February 13, 1796 nullifying the Yazoo Act. The state burned all copies of the bill except for one that had been sent to President George Washington. Jackson resigned as Senator to run for office as next Governor of Georgia. He was elected and took office two years later.Magrath, C. Peter. (1966)''Yazoo: Law and Politics in the New Republic. The Case of 'Fletcher v. Peck'.'' (1966). Providence, R.I.: Brown University Press Mathews started afresh in the [[Mississippi Territory]]. His wife Polly had died, so he married a widow, Mary (Fairchild) (Lewis) Carpenter (widow of Richard Carpenter, 1729–1788.Terry L. Carpenter: "Richard Carpenter, Pioneer Merchant of British West Florida and the Natchez District of Spanish West Florida", in ''The National Genealogical Society Quarterly'', Vol. 72, No. 1, March 1984, pp. 51-62.), who owned property there. He again returned to land speculation, buying stock in a land company the claimant of extensive acreage in the territory. A few years later he would also return to politics. In 1798 he was appointed governor of the newly formed territory of Mississippi by President [[John Adams]]. [[Secretary of War]] [[James McHenry]] objected to the appointment, citing Mathews' financial stake in the territory. When Adams withdrew the nomination, Mathews was reported to have responded: "Sir, if you had known me, you wouldn't have taken the nomination back; if you didn't know me, you should not have nominated me to such an important office." == Patriot War of East Florida == [[File:West Florida Map 1767.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|[[West Florida]], the original target of Gen. Mathews' mission to annex the Floridas for the United States.]] "The East Florida revolution of 1812 was an embarrassing and shameful moment in the history of early American foreign policy." {{cite journal|last1=Stagg|first1=J. C. A.|title=James Madison and George Mathews: The East Florida Revolution of 1812 Reconsidered|journal=Diplomatic History|date=2006|volume=30|issue=1|page=23|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=19148899&site=eds-live&scope=site|accessdate=31 May 2016|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7709.2006.00536.x}} In 1810, Mathews was recommended to President [[James Madison]] by Georgia Senator [[William Harris Crawford]] as a confidential agent to report on conditions in the Spanish Floridas, as Crawford believed an annexation of the territory to the United States was possible. Fearing the collapse of Spanish rule, President Madison sent Mathews to meet with Spanish governor of [[West Florida]], Don [[Vicente Folch]], in November, 1810, to inform the residents of East Florida that if they were to separate from Spain they would be welcomed into the United States.{{cite book|last1=Herring|first1=George C.|title=From Colony To Superpower : U.S. Foreign Relations Since 1776|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780199743773|page=111|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nlebk&AN=257637&site=eds-live&scope=site&ebv=EB&ppid=pp_111|accessdate=31 May 2016}} Folch indicated to Mathews that he was willing to transfer West Florida to the United States peacefully. Madison, on receiving this information, decided to try to [[Annexation|annex]] both East and West Florida all at once, seeking to take West Florida peacefully and giving Mathews "official instructions to assist a revolutionary movement in East Florida." Mathews was assigned an Indian agent, [[John McKee]]. The president, seeking to keep the United States seemingly removed from the plan, gave them instructions that were "remarkably vague and general."{{cite book|author=Stephen F. Knott|title=Secret and Sanctioned: Covert Operations and the American Presidency|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DgYxLklV7UwC&pg=PA93|year=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-510098-3|page=93}} Mathews, then at 72 years of age, returned to the Spanish state with a commission of [[Brigadier General|brigadier general]] and again met with Governor Folch. Folch had gone cold on the trade and told Mathews that he did not intend to negotiate with Madison for the West. Mathews delivered the message to the White House, at which point [[Secretary of State]] [[James Monroe]] instructed Mathews to focus on forceful annexation of East Florida, "if he thought he could accomplish anything there." [[File:East Florida Patriot Flag.svg|thumb|right|upright=1.0|East Florida Patriot Flag, raised by the Patriot Army at Fernandina]] Mathews and McKee proceeded in the subsequent months to create an intelligence network throughout East Florida to ascertain the political attitudes of the East Floridians towards the United States, determining that an insurrection against Spanish rule was achievable. Mathews became infected with [[malaria]] during the campaign, delaying the operation several months. Isaac Cox wrote that Mathews "spent the summer of 1811 alternately fighting malaria and encouraging insurrection." On March 13, 1812, Mathews, with a force of Georgians, launched his revolution at [[Original Town of Fernandina Historic Site#History|Fernandina]] on [[Amelia Island]]. With Mathews, the local insurgents known as the "Patriots of Amelia Island" seized the island and declared their independence. They hoisted a new flag of East Florida, designed by a member of Mathews' staff.{{cite book|last=Cusick|first=James G.|title=The other war of 1812 : the Patriot War and the American invasion of Spanish East Florida|year=2007|publisher=University of Georgia Press|location=Athens, Georgia|isbn=978-0820329215|page=32}} He then turned his focus inland, writing to the President{{cite book|title=The Papers of James Madison, Presidential Series, vol. 4, 5 November 1811-9 July 1812 and supplement 5 March 1809-19 October 1811|date=1999|publisher=University Press of Virginia|location=Charlottesville|pages=326|url=https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Madison/03-04-02-0341|accessdate=13 May 2016}} to convey the success and to request additional United States military personnel. As the insurrection grew, Congress became alarmed at the possibility of being drawn into war with Spain and their allies, the British. (However, a few months later the U.S. declared war on Britain, setting off the [[War of 1812]]). Mathews' operation had grown large enough and quickly enough that the United States could no longer deny involvement.{{cite web|last1=Monroe|first1=James|title=[Letter] 1812 Oct. 13, Department of State, [Washington, D.C. to] David B. Mitchell / Ja[me]s Monroe|url=http://dlg.galileo.usg.edu/zlna/id:krc128|website=Southeastern Native American Documents, 1730–1842|publisher=Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=31 May 2016}} Madison was forced to repudiate the mission, and the effort fell apart. He and his cabinet would deny all involvement in the matter. Mathews decided to go to Washington to appeal his case personally. But, on the trip he became ill and was forced to stop in [[Augusta, Georgia]]. He died without reaching Washington. ===Interpretations=== Historians have been divided over the legacy of the Patriot War of East Florida. Some agree that Mathews overstepped his authority and deliberately departed from Madison's intentions. Historian J.C.A. Stagg, in ''George Mathews and John McKee, Revolutionizing East Florida, Mobile, and Pensacola in 1812'' (2007), found sufficient evidence in correspondence between Mathews and Madison to determine that Mathews exaggerated his "remarkably vague" instructions and acted well beyond Madison's intent. {{quote box |width = 50em |border = 1px |align = center |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |halign = left |quote = It has become conventional to regard the East Florida revolution of 1812 as a singularly colorful and controversial episode in the history of the early republic. Its colorful aspects have lent themselves to the writing of fast-paced narratives that make for good reading because its organizers -- United States government agents George Mathews and John McKee -- brought to the performance of their duties roughly equal proportions of outright illegality, low intrigue, and not a little incompetence. It is now reasonably clear that the actions of Mathews and McKee in Florida and on the Gulf Coast between 1810 and 1812 departed far more from the policies of the [Madison] administration than they fairly reflected them. |source= — J. C. A. Scagg, ''George Mathews and John McKee, Revolutionizing East Florida, Mobile, and Pensacola in 1812'' (2007) Stagg, J.C.A. (2007). George Mathews and John McKee: Revolutionizing East Florida, Mobile, and Pensacola in 1812. The Florida Historical Quarterly Vol. 85, No. 3 (Winter, 2007). pp. 269-296 }} Others believe Mathews had followed Madison's intentions, and that Madison had disowned the filibuster for political reasons, sacrificing Mathews' reputation in the process. Historian G. Melvin Herndon, in ''George Mathews, Frontier Patriot'' (1969), offered a vindicating perspective for Mathews and places blame for the failure of the expedition on Madison for repudiating the assignment. {{quote box |width = 50em |border = 1px |align = center |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |halign = left |quote = It is generally agreed that Mathews was the victim of a vacillating administration whose dictates he had served faithfully according to his own lights. He succeeded too well; and, under pressure from several sources, President Madison and Secretary Monroe deemed it necessary to sacrifice Mathews to quell the criticism of their Florida policy. |source= — G. Melvin Herndon, ''George Mathews, Frontier Patriot'' (1969) }} ==Death and honors== [[File:George Mathews later life.jpg|thumb|George Mathews later in life]] Mathews died on his 73rd birthday, August 30, 1812, in [[Augusta, Georgia]], while on his way to Washington to confront President Madison over the repudiation of his filibuster expedition. He is buried in St. Paul's Churchyard there. *[[Mathews, Alabama]], is named for him.{{cite web|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=68716|title=The Jonesville Community Historical Marker|publisher=}} *[[Mathews, Louisiana]], is named for his son, [[George Mathews (judge)|George Mathews Jr.]] * Several [[historical markers]] in Georgia are dedicated to him.{{cite web|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=37157|title=Governor Mathews' Homesite Historical Marker|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=15809|title=Fort Mathews [[Goelet family]] | estate = | related names = | clans = | footnotes = | nolinklanguage = }} The '''Havemeyer family''' is a prominent family from [[New York (state)|New York]], of [[Germany|German]] origins, that owned significant sugar refining interests in the [[United States]].{{cite web|title=Sugar and Columbia University|url=https://slaveryexhibits.ctl.columbia.edu/exhibits/show/sugarcolumbia |website=Columbia University|accessdate=11 July 2018|language=en}} ==History== William Havemeyer (1770-1851) left [[Germany]] at age 15 and arrived in [[New York City]] after learning the trade of sugar refining in [[London]]. In New York he managed a sugar house on Pine Street before opening his own refinery on [[Vandam Street (Manhattan)|Vandam Street]] with his brother, Frederick Christian Havemeyer, who had come to New York in 1802. Together the two brothers operated the '''W. & F.C. Havemeyer Company''' sugar refineries, before passing the business on to their sons.{{cite book|title=Life, Letters and Addresses of John Craig Havemeyer|url=https://archive.org/details/lifelettersanda00havegoog|accessdate=9 July 2018}} His son [[William Frederick Havemeyer]], retired from the sugar refining business in 1842 and entered politics, eventually serving three terms as Mayor of New York.{{cite book|title=The Business World, Volume 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HnsiAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA1217&dq=William+Frederick+Havemeyer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwih6Zqs4JPcAhVRMawKHaNVCCcQ6AEIPDAF#v=onepage&q=William%20Frederick%20Havemeyer&f=false|accessdate=9 July 2018}}{{cite web|title=Charles F. Chandler, The Havemeyer Family, And New York City Politics|url=https://slaveryexhibits.ctl.columbia.edu/exhibits/show/sugarcolumbia/chandlerhavemeyernyc|website=Columbia University|accessdate=11 July 2018|language=en}} In 1855 the family relocated their refineries to [[Brooklyn]], where they remained as the business grew to acquire a commanding share of the United States sugar refining market under the leadership of Frederick's grandson, [[Henry Osborne Havemeyer]]. The Havemeyer refineries were incorporated as the [[American Sugar Refining Company]] in 1891 and became known as [[Domino Sugar]] in 1900.{{cite web|last1=Diamond|first1=Anna|title=These Photos of the Abandoned Domino Sugar Refinery Document Its Sticky History|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/photos-abandoned-domino-sugar-refinery-document-sticky-history-180967578/|website=Smithsonian|accessdate=19 March 2018|language=en}} In the 20th century several of the family's members made notable contributions to the arts. [[Henry Osborne Havemeyer]] and his wife [[Louisine Havemeyer]] made large bequests to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] and their daughter [[Electra Havemeyer Webb]] founded the [[Shelburne Museum]].{{cite web|title=Who Were the Havemeyers?|url=https://www.brownstoner.com/history/who-were-the-ha/|website=Brownstoner|accessdate=11 July 2018|language=en}}{{cite web|title=Splendid Legacy: The Havemeyer Collection|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/metpublications/Splendid_Legacy_The_Havemeyer_Collection|website=Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=11 July 2018|language=en}} [[File:William Frederick Havemeyer.jpg|thumb|Mayor [[William Frederick Havemeyer]] (1804-1874)]] ==Family tree== {{Tree list}} * William Havemeyer (1770-1851) ∞ Susannah Clegg (1781-1838){{cite book|title=Life, Letters and Addresses of John Craig Havemeyer|url=https://archive.org/details/lifelettersanda00havegoog|accessdate=9 July 2018}} ** [[William Frederick Havemeyer]] (1804-1874) ∞ Sarah Agnes Craig (1807-1894) *** John Craig Havemeyer (1832-1922) {{cite news|title=John C. The '''Howard Hughes Memorial Award''' is an aviation industry award presented annually by the Aero Club of Southern California. According to the Association's official website, the award is given "to an aerospace leader whose accomplishments over a long career have contributed significantly to the advancement of aviation or space technology."
The award was established in 1978 by William R. Lummis, a first cousin of aviation pioneer [[Howard Hughes]], who at the time was [[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[Summa Corp.]]. Recipients of the Howard Hughes Memorial Award receive a solid [[silver]] medallion cast from silver mined from Hughes' [[Nevada]] mining operations.
== Recipients == * [[Jack Northrop]] * [[Jimmy Doolittle]] * [[Lawrence A. Hyland]] * [[Robert Six]] * [[Clarence Johnson|Kelly Johnson]] * [[Chuck Yeager]] * [[Ed Heinemann]] * [[Barry Goldwater]] * [[Pete Conrad]] * [[Allen E. revision.text:
'''Ian Robert Anderson MacCallum''' (1931 – 5 April 2013) was a British solicitor and politician in Hong Kong.
MacCallum was a soldier at the [[Royal Army Service Corps]] before he was admitted as a solicitor of England and Wales in 1953 and then of Hong Kong in 1956. He started his practice from 1956 to 1994 in Hong Kong. He was the senior partner of the leading law firm Wilkinson & Grist.
He served in many public offices, including the membership of the council from 1969, vice-president in 1973, president in 1975 and 1976 and the membership Roll of Honour of the [[Law Society of Hong Kong]] and a core member of the [[Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce]]. MacCallum was also Chairman of the Hong Kong Branch of Civil Rights Group Justice in the 1970s and 1980s.
In 1985 he was appointed to the [[Hong Kong Basic Law Consultative Committee]], a consultative committee for the drafting of the [[Basic Law of Hong Kong]]. He was part of the conservative wing [[Group of 89]] in the committee resisting the faster pace of democratisation. He initially intended to run in the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 1988|1988 Legislative Council election]] for the [[Commercial (First)|First Commercial]] [[functional constituency (Hong Kong)|functional constituency]] elected by the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. However, he was persuaded by the Group of 89 to make way for Veronica Wu, daughter-in-law of tycoon [[Cha Chi-ming]], who eventually lost to [[Jimmy McGregor]].<ref name="party">{{cite news|title=It's party time for Hongkong's politicians|first=Bernard|last=Fong|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=20 August 1988}}</ref>
MacCallum also served in voluntary positions in the [[Salvation Army]], the Methodist International Church, [[St. James' Settlement (Hong Kong)|St. James’ Settlement]], Hong Kong Bible Society and Friends of Cambridge University Prince Philip Scholarships and Honorary Permanent President of the [[HKBU]] Foundation. He was the vice-chairman and a founding trustee of the Croucher Foundation appointed by Noel Croucher.<ref name="Croucher">{{cite web|title=Tribute: Ian MacCallum|url=https://croucher.org.hk/ian-maccallum-vice-chairman-and-trustee-of-the-croucher-foundation-died-on-5th-april-2013-aged-82|work=Croucher Foundation}}</ref>
MacCallum died on 5 April 2013, aged 82.<ref name="Croucher"/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox NRHP | name = John Cabot House | nrhp_type = | image = John Cabot House - Beverly, Massachusetts.JPG | caption = | location = 117 Cabot Street
[[Beverly, Massachusetts]] | coordinates = {{coord|42|32|45|N|70|52|48|W|region:US-MA_type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | locmapin = Massachusetts#USA | area = | built = {{start date|1781}} | architecture = Late Georgian/Early Federal | designated = | added = April 16, 1975 | refnum = 75000246{{NRISref|2008a}} | governing_body = [[Beverly Historical Society]] | nrhp_type2 = cp | designated_nrhp_type2 = July 5, 1984 | partof = [[Beverly Center Business District]] | partof_refnum = 84002313 }} The '''John Cabot House''' is a [[historic house]] at 117 Cabot Street in downtown [[Beverly, Massachusetts]]. Built in 1781 by a prominent local businessman and ship owner, it was the town's first brick mansion house. It is now owned by Historic Beverly and open to the public five days a week. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1975. ==Description== The John Cabot House is located in Beverly's downtown business district, on the east side of Cabot Street (its major thoroughfare) between Central Street and Franklin Place. It is a three-story timber-framed structure, its exterior clad in red brick and capped by a truncated hip roof. The main facade is five bays wide, with windows set in rectangular openings with splayed soldier brick headers. Projecting brick courses separate the floors, and the third-floor windows are smaller in height, and butt against the elaborate dentillated roof cornice. The main entrance projects slightly in a surround that includes sidelight windows, pilasters, and a corniced entablature. The interior has a typical central stair plan, and retains most of its original woodwork, which is in a heavy late Georgian style.{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=BEV.101|title=NRHP nomination and MACRIS inventory record for John Cabot House|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2016-12-20}} ==History== The house was built in 1781, and was the first brick mansion in Beverly.{{cite web|url=http://www.beverlyhistory.org/houses/cabot.html|title=Houses: The John Cabot House|first=|last=|publisher=[[Beverly Historical Society]]|date=|accessdate=January 11, 2012}} It was built for shipowner and privateer [[Capt. John Cabot]] (b. 1745 in [[Salem, Massachusetts|Salem]] to Joseph Cabot and Elizabeth Higginson).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WG8MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA275&lpg=PA275|title=Historical collections of the Essex Institute, Volume IV|first=G.M.|last=Whipple|publisher=[[Essex Institute]]|date=1862|accessdate=January 11, 2012}} Cabot was prominent in the town's economy, having also cofounded the [[Beverly Cotton Manufactory]], America's first cotton mill.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YEhBAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA206&lpg=PA206|title=Paine Ancestry: The Family of Robert Treat Paine, Signer of the Declaration of Independence|first=Sarah Cushing|last=Paine|publisher=David Clapp & Son|date=1912|accessdate=January 11, 2012}} In 1802, the house became the first office of the Beverly Bank, the tenth oldest bank in America, with Capt. John Cabot serving as one of seven original directors. At that time, it was extended to the rear by a two-story wood-frame addition. In addition to period rooms, the John Cabot House features maritime, military, and children's exhibits as well as major changing exhibits. Historic Beverly's research facilities are also located here. ==See also== *[[John Balch House]], another Beverly Historical Society property *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Essex County, Massachusetts]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.historicbeverly.net Historic Beverly] {{National Register of Historic Places in Massachusetts}} [[Category:Cabot family]] [[Category:Houses completed in 1781]] [[Category:Historic house museums in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Museums in Essex County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Houses in Beverly, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Houses on the National Register of Historic Places in Essex County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Massachusetts]]
